artist: Katsushika Hokusai; Poem by Yōdaijo; Published by Nishimuraya Yohachi
marks: Oshiroi no / hana ya / botan no ushirogaki, Yōdaij Saki no Hokusai Iitsu hitsu 前北斎為一筆
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
text: Four-o’clocks were introduced to Japan in the early 17th century and became popular among amateur horticulturists. To protect the flowers from direct sunlight, gardeners typically planted four-o’clocks near a fence, as mentioned in the poem. In contrast to the large, showy blooms of peonies, the “king of flowers,” which thrive in sunlight, four-o’clock blossoms are small and modest, discreetly opening late in the day and withering in the morning sun. Orange gradation along the print’s upper edge suggests sunset, when four-o’clocks are open. The poem is ascribed to “a woman of Yōdai.” A reference to fairyland or the moon, Yōdai implies the poet has super- natural beauty. Four-o’clocks bloom near the fence behind the peonies.
title: Hawfinch and Marvel-of-Peru
